title: How to Turn on Bluetooth on Your iPhone or Android: 4 Easy Methods

steps.title: Swipe down from the top-right corner of your phone.
steps.content: Swipe down from the top-right corner of your phone. This will open the Control Center, which allows you to easily adjust some settings on your iPhone without having to open the Settings app. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the Bluetooth button in the upper-left corner.
steps.content: Tap the Bluetooth button in the upper-left corner. In the section in the upper-left corner of the Control Center, the Bluetooth button is in the bottom-right. The icon looks like a "B". The Bluetooth button will turn blue once it is active.

steps.title: Open your Settings app.
steps.content: Open your Settings app. The Settings application gives you various options to modify your phone and change other application settings.

steps.title: Click Bluetooth.
steps.content: Click Bluetooth. This should be your third option within settings.

steps.title: Tap the switch next to Bluetooth.
steps.content: Tap the switch next to Bluetooth. This will turn on Bluetooth and automatically search for devices that are near enough to connect to.

steps.title: Swipe down from the top-left of your screen.
steps.content: Swipe down from the top-left of your screen. This will open the Quick Settings menu.

steps.title: Tap the Bluetooth icon.
steps.content: Tap the Bluetooth icon. Depending on your phone model, the Bluetooth icon may be in a different location, but the icon looks like a "B". Once you tap the Bluetooth icon, the background will turn blue to show that it's active.

steps.title: Swipe down again if you don't see the Bluetooth option.
steps.content: Swipe down again if you don't see the Bluetooth option. Swiping down a second time will expand the Quick Settings menu. From this menu you should be able to enable Bluetooth.

steps.title: Locate and open your settings menu.
steps.content: Locate and open your settings menu. The logo for the settings menu is a cogwheel. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Find your connection settings.
steps.content: Find your connection settings. The name of this menu item varies depending on what phone model you have. On a Google Pixel you'll want to look for Connected devices and on Samsung you'll want to look for Connections . [4] X Research source [5] X Research source On a Google Pixel, you must also select the Connection preferences option after selecting Connected devices .

steps.title: Toggle on Bluetooth.
steps.content: Toggle on Bluetooth. After you turn on Bluetooth, your phone will start searching for nearby Bluetooth devices.

steps.title: Restart your device.
steps.content: Restart your device. Many times your phone, like a computer, can overheat or just be running for too long of a period. Sometimes we don't think of our phones as a computer, but phones can benefit from a simple reboot. After turning off your device, wait one minute before restarting it.

steps.title: Turn airplane mode on and off.
steps.content: Turn airplane mode on and off. This is known as a "soft reset" and can help fix some network and connection problems. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Perform an update.
steps.content: Perform an update. If your phone's operating system is out of date, you could be missing out on an important bug fix for Bluetooth. You'll often need to either be connected to a computer or Wi-Fi to perform an update. This process takes some time, so be ready with your charger nearby.

steps.title: Delete a device from your Bluetooth list.
steps.content: Delete a device from your Bluetooth list. If you are having trouble with a device you've already paired your phone with, try starting from scratch. [7] X Research source
